awd_titl_txt: Bridging the Gap in Automated and Connected Vehicle Technology Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Profound developments in research and resources are feeding technological advancements that will soon make self-driving vehicles commonplace. Today's leading-edge, semi-autonomous connected vehicles utilize technology that includes radars, cameras, lidar, multi-domain controllers, wireless vehicle-to-vehicle communications, and software applications, to name a few. The proposed postsecondary faculty professional development project, focused on automated and connected vehicle technology, will serve the NSF's mission of promoting the progress of science by creating industry-supported workshops and college-level educational resources to academically strengthen postsecondary automotive technician degree programs. Project activities such as summer institutes and professional development webinars for faculty will be designed to advance the field of vehicle technology education across the country by informing the educators of future technicians about the new generation of vehicles that are radically changing the automotive and transportation industries. In addition to professional development, the autonomous vehicles and other materials purchased through the grant will also be used to provide outreach activities in secondary schools, including creating a toolkit comprised of interactive demonstrations designed to orient secondary school students, teachers, and counselors to automotive technician educational pathways and careers. 

Auto technician education must keep pace with the complexity of vehicles that incorporate aspects of robotics, machine learning, computer vision, and mechanical engineering. The goal of the proposed project is to increase the autonomous vehicle technology experience and knowledge of automotive technology educators throughout the nation and address the growing need for qualified, knowledgeable technicians with capacity to maintain and repair autonomous vehicles. The project will provide a week-long professional development session, webinars, and other learning events for 40 community college faculty annually. The project will also conduct outreach activities in secondary schools to impart information about the high wage, high-tech nature of the work of automotive technicians, important since many secondary school students skilled in science, math, and technology are not choosing automotive technician careers due in part to their misconceptions about what the work entails. The project will also monitor and document the skills and knowledge needed by the future automotive technician who will repair and maintain vehicles using a new set of skills not taught today. The project outcomes will be useful to other institutions with automotive technician education programs that need to update their curriculum to meet the changing needs in the industry or are struggling to diversify their student population interested in automotive technology careers.

por.por_cntn:
The proposal "Bridging the gap in Automated and Connected Vehicle Technology" overall goal was to create industry-supported workshops and educational resources to academically strengthen automotive technician degree programs and meet employers' needs for technicians who are skilled and knowledgeable about autonomous and connected vehicle technology.  The objectives of the project were to:

  1. Increase the capacity of accredited institutions across the country to prepare automotive technicians to repair and service autonomous and connected vehicles.
  2. Increase the number of technician graduates with the knowledge and skills needed to diagnose and repair semi-autonomous and autonomous vehicles.
  3. Increase the number of high school students who enroll in automotive technology programs.
  4. Explore and document the skills needed by automotive technicians servicing automated and connected vehicles.

 

The project team delivered three, 40-hour summer institutes focusing on technical training to prepare automotive instructors to teach theory, operation, service and repair of autonomous systems found on today?s passenger production vehicles.  These systems are referred to as Advance Driver Assist Systems (ADAS). ADAS encompasses the technology listed below:

  • Pedestrian detection/avoidance
  • Lane departure warning/correction
  • Traffic sign recognition
  • Automatic emergency braking
  • Blind spot detection
  • Driver assistance ex: Autopilot, DrivePilot, EyeSight, Supercruise, etc

The summer institutes participated in recalibrations of cameras and radar systems utilizing the latest industry calibration equipment to ensure proper operation.  Attendees from the institutes utilized these skills to prepare lessons delivered at their automotive technology institutions, preparing the future workforce to service these advanced systems.

As the automotive industry focus shifted from semi-autonomous features to electrification of passenger vehicles, the project team requested supplemental funding to offer an advanced summer institute to previous attendees.  The 24 hour advanced institute focused on theory, operation, service and repair of battery electric vehicles and supporting systems.  The systems covered at the institute were:

  • BEV Introduction, Theory & Operation, & Safety
  • High voltage (HV) disabling
  • High voltage battery pack removal & installation lab
  • BEV Charging and Levels lecture
  • DC to DC converter, FEV 100 charging station tester
  • Milli / Mega Ohmmeter testing
  • BEV Cooling & Heating system
  • Diagnosis of BEV faults

The advanced battery electric vehicle institute provided automotive faculty from across the nation the knowledge and skills to build automotive technology labs preparing graduates to service these unique vehicles.

Throughout the project, the team engaged in targeted outreach with K-12 students, specifically with underrepresented populations in the automotive industry.  The focus was to educate and recruit more talent for the automotive industry, using the emerging technology as the lure. The outreach consisted of the following events, to educate students about emerging technologies in the automotive industry, the disciplines that contribute to the technology and the careers supporting automated, connected and electrified technology:

  • Engineering and Technologies High School Visit Day
  • Girl Scout Automotive Badge
  • Women in STEM
  • Tech Prep Automotive Days
  • Middle school career days
  • Automotive Technology Middle School Summer Camp

The project successfully delivered four institutes and provided educational resources to strengthen automotive technician degree programs, while meeting employers' needs for technicians who are skilled and knowledgeable to service, diagnose and repair automated and connected vehicle technology, as well as battery electric vehicles.  In May of 2022, Automotive Service Excellence (ASE) launched a new Advanced Driver Assistance Specialist Certification Test (L4), further demonstrating the need for automotive technicians with this skill set and confirming the projects overarching goals.

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2022
Modified by: Justin Morgan
